name: hard coal preparation, coal washing | hard coal | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/17949/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of beneficiated coal in South Africa. Around 66% of South Africa's saleable coal has undergone coal washing, predominantly by dense media separation (SACRM, 2011). The washed coal product supplies both the domestic and export coal market, with many mines producing both a middlings product (often supplied to power generation), and a higher quality product for export. Total production in 2014 amounted to 172 million tonnes (DMR, 2015). This dataset includes the waste coal produced (discard), the land required for its disposal, methane emissions associated with coal preparation and storage, water and magnetite required in washing, and emissions to surface water. Energy use and the land area of the coal preparation plant are not included because disaggregated data was not available for the mining operations. Similarly, where generic mining factors have been used in the mining datasets (e.g. for particulates and infrastructure), these are assumed to include coal preparation.  ;;Reference(s): ;SACRM (2011) Overview of South African Coal Value Chain. Available at: http://www.sanedi.org.za/archived/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/sacrm value chain overview.pdf (Accessed: July 2015); ;DMR (2015) Mineral Production and Sales and Mining Labour Statistics Tables 1993 - 2014, Department of Mineral Resources. Available at: http://www.dmr.gov.za/ (Accessed: March 2017).;[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:]

Coal preparation (crushing, screening and dense medium washing), starting from hard coal, run-of mine.

This activity ends with 1 kg hard coal (useable output) at the coal preparation facility. This dataset includes coal waste produced and land used for coal waste disposal, magnetite and water used in coal washing, and emissions to water, Energy use and land for the coal preparation plant are not included in this dataset as they are included in the mining datasets (they were not able to be disaggregated from the mining data). Particulates are similarly not included because the generic value applied in the mining datasets is assumed to include coal preparation..
category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

processDocumentation.timeDescription: 2014 is chosen as a base year because this is the latest year for which coal production and yield data were available (i.e. the most recent government statistics on coal mining). The industry data on which the dataset is based is somewhat earlier than 2014 (mid 2000 to 2010), but expert opinion consulted is that mining operations have not changed much over this time, thus it made sense to use the most recent production data. The water balance data used in the dataset is older (2001), and expert opinion is used to adjust for efficiency improvements, so that water consumption and emissions are represenative of 2014.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Coal preparation efficiency is representative of coal mining in South Africa as a whole, with the land requirements for disposal, and other coal washing inputs (water and magnetite) extrapolated from collieries mining the Witbank, Highveld and Waterberg coalfields in South Africa. Infrastructure requriements are generic (not South African specific). Rehabilitation of the mine dumps post closure is not included.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset is representative of coal beneficiation in South Africa (crushing, screening and dense medium washing), The dataset is an average over a number of mines, and thus is not representative of single- or multi-stage washing, but rather represents an average. A coal preparation efficiency of 70% is applied. This value is representative of South Africa as a whole as it is derived from
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Production volume is from DMR (2015), with the percentage of coal undergoing beneficiation from SACRM (2011). An average coal washing yield is calculated from the overall coal preparation effiency for South Africa (77% in 2014, from DMR (2015)) and an assumed crushing yield of 98%. Methane emissions are calculated using post-mining emission factors derived for South Africa's national GHG reporting (DEA, 2014). Land use for dump areas are from three mines with washing plants (ranging from simple to extensive). Water required for coal washing is from a water balance project for South Africa (Pulles et al., 2001) References: Department of Minerals and Resources (2015) South Africa's Mineral Industry (SAMI) 2014/2015. Pretoria; DEA (2014) GHG NATIONAL INVENTORY REPORT SOUTH AFRICA 2000 -2010, November 2014. http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/natc/zafnir1.pdf (accessed September 2017);  Pulles, W., Boer, R. & Nel, S. 2001. A Generic Water Balance for the South African Coal Mining Industry. Water 
Research Commission Report No. 801/1/01; SACRM (2011) Overview of South African Coal Value Chain. Available at: http://www.sanedi.org.za/archived/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/sacrm value chain overview.pdf (Accessed: July 2015).

exchanges.description: Approximate value, calculated from concentration in representative sample of effluent multiplied by estimate of volume of water discharged to rivers (industry data).
Assumes active dump area lifetime of 30 years and revegetation time of 25 years. A relatively long time is chosen as dumps present the greatest challenge to rehabilitation of coal mines.

EcoSpold01Location=GLO
Weight of coal discard in slurry (excluding weight of water). Rough estimate using old data source (DMR, 2001) reporting that 20% of total coal waste produced nationally is in the form of fines slurry. According to a national inventory of discard and duff coal in South Africa in 2001, 4-6% of coal beneficiated ends up as fines slurry. Reference: DMR (2001) National Inventory Discard and Duff Coal - 2--1 Summary Report, Department of Mineral resources of South Africa Available at: http://www.energy.gov.za/Coal/coal_discard_report.pdf. (Accessed August 2017).

exchanges.description: Coal supply fom underground mines. An overall coal preparation yield of 70% is applied, resulting in 440 kg coal waste per tonne coal product. The washing yield is derived from the overall yield for the coal mining industry in 2014 (77%) (DMR, 2015) and an assumed yield of 98% for coal undergoing crushing and destoning only. The derived value aligns with available industry data (average coal preparation yield of SACRM mine data sample is 73%, ranging from 54%-80%). Using a combination of DMR (2015) and SACMR (2011) production statistics, coal supply to coal preparation that includes washing is as follows: 18% from underground mining, 53% for surface, dragline, and 29% from surface, truck and shovel.  Reference(s): Department of Minerals and Resources (2015) South Africa's Mineral Industry (SAMI) 2014/2015. Pretoria; The South African Coal Roadmap (SACRM) (2011). Overview of the South African Coal Value Chain. http://www.sanedi.org.za/archived/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/sacrm%20value%20chain%20overview.pdf.

exchanges.description: The share of water inputs from rain as well as that for which the source is not known is included in the dataset under "unspecified natural origin". The value are taken from Pulles et al. (2001), in which a sample of 41 mines found that, on average, the origin of 13% of water inputs were not known/specified and 3% of water input was from rain ingress.Total water use by coal washing is taken to be 150  litres/tonne ROM, A slightly lower value is applied than that in Pulles et al. (2001) (which has an average value of 217 litres/tonne ROM  from a sample of 32 mines) to account for improvements in coal dewatering since 2001 (Johan de Korte, 2017). References: Pulles, W., Boer, R. & Nel, S. 2001. A Generic Water Balance for the South African Coal Mining Industry. Water Research Commission Report No. 801/1/01.; Johan de Korte, Senior Researcher, Council for Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR), telephonic interview, 7 June 2017.

Calculated value, assuming 22% of water output is as a result of discharge to surface water bodies. Share of water loss is taken from Pulles et al. (2001). Total water use by washing is assumed to be 150  litres/tonne ROM, A lower value is applied than in Pulles et al. (2001) (which has an average value of 217 litres/tonne ROM  from a sample of 32 mines) to account for improvements in coal dewatering since 2001 (Johan de Korte, 2017). References: Pulles, W., Boer, R. & Nel, S. 2001. A Generic Water Balance for the South African Coal Mining Industry. Water Research Commission Report No. 801/1/01.; Johan de Korte, Senior Researcher, Council for Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR), telephonic interview, 7 June 2017.

Coal supply from surface dragline mines. An overall coal preparation yield of 70% is applied, resulting in 440 kg coal waste per tonne coal product. The washing yield is derived from the overall yield for the coal mining industry in 2014 (77%) (DMR, 2015) and an assumed yield of 98% for coal undergoing crushing and destoning only. The derived value aligns with available industry data (average coal preparation yield of SACRM mine data sample is 73%, ranging from 54%-80%). Using a combination of DMR (2015) and SACMR (2011) production statistics, coal supply to coal preparation that includes washing is as follows: 18% from underground mining, 53% for surface, dragline, and 29% from surface, truck and shovel.  Reference(s): Department of Minerals and Resources (2015) South Africa's Mineral Industry (SAMI) 2014/2015. Pretoria; The South African Coal Roadmap (SACRM) (2011). Overview of the South African Coal Value Chain. http://www.sanedi.org.za/archived/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/sacrm%20value%20chain%20overview.pdf.

exchanges.description: Total land transformed for mineral extraction activities at 10 collieries in South Africa, assuming constant coal production over a 30 year mine life (industry data), with 20% of land use designated as coal and spoil disposal areas. Value derived from three coal mines that had washing plants and provided disaggregated land use data, with the percentage share of total area taken up by discard and spoil disposal (inluding slurry dams, where relevant) ranging from 12% to 39%.

Coal supply from surface truck and shovel mines. An overall coal preparation yield of 70% is applied, resulting in 440 kg coal waste per tonne coal product. The washing yield is derived from the overall yield for the coal mining industry in 2014 (77%) (DMR, 2015) and an assumed yield of 98% for coal undergoing crushing and destoning only. The derived value aligns with available industry data (average coal preparation yield of SACRM mine data sample is 73%, ranging from 54%-80%). Using a combination of DMR (2015) and SACMR (2011) production statistics, coal supply to coal preparation that includes washing is as follows: 18% from underground mining, 53% for surface, dragline, and 29% from surface, truck and shovel.  Reference(s): Department of Minerals and Resources (2015) South Africa's Mineral Industry (SAMI) 2014/2015. Pretoria; The South African Coal Roadmap (SACRM) (2011). Overview of the South African Coal Value Chain. http://www.sanedi.org.za/archived/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/sacrm%20value%20chain%20overview.pdf.

exchanges.description: Average share of water used in coal washing filled by groundwater taken from Pulles et al. (2001), in which a sample of 41 mines found that groundwater supplied 39% of the water used on the mine. Total water use by coal washing is taken to be 150  litres/tonne ROM, A slightly lower value is applied than that in Pulles et al. (2001) (which has an average value of 217 litres/tonne ROM  from a sample of 32 mines) to account for improvements in coal dewatering since 2001 (Johan de Korte, 2017). References: Pulles, W., Boer, R. & Nel, S. 2001. A Generic Water Balance for the South African Coal Mining Industry. Water Research Commission Report No. 801/1/01.; Johan de Korte, Senior Researcher, Council for Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR), telephonic interview, 7 June 2017.

Total land transformed for mineral extraction activities at 10 collieries in South Africa, assuming constant coal production over a 30 year mine life (industry data), with 20% of land use designated as coal and spoil disposal areas. Value derived from three coal mines that had washing plants and provided disaggregated land use data, with the percentage share of total area taken up by discard and spoil disposal (inluding slurry dams, where relevant) ranging from 12% to 39%. Coal mines fall predominantly in the grasslands regions of South Africa, thus this is chosen as the default.

flow.name: Transformation, from grassland, natural, for livestock grazing

exchanges.description: Approximate value, calculated from concentration in representative sample of effluent multiplied by estimate of volume of water discharged to rivers (industry data).

Approximate value, calculated from concentration in representative sample of mining effluent (dirty storage dam) multiplied by estimate of water loss through seepage (industry data). Most likely an overestimate as unspecified water outtputs are assumed to be seepage losses. Calculation also does not allow for attenuation in soils.
Approximate value, calculated from concentration in representative sample of effluent multiplied by estimate of volume of water discharged to rivers (industry data).
Approximate value, calculated from TDS value in representative sample of efluent multiplied by estimate of water discharged to rivers (industry data).

Emission factor taken from South Africa's National GHG Inventory for post-mining coal handling and storage (0.18 m3/tonne, underground mine). Emission factor is for underground coal only, with surface coal given an emission factor of 0. The emissions are therefore adjusted for the percenatge of coal undergoing washing supplied from surface mines. Reference:  Department of Environment (2014) GHG NATIONAL INVENTORY REPORT SOUTH AFRICA 2000 -2010, November 2014. http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/natc/zafnir1.pdf

flow.name: Methane, fossil
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
An overall coal preparation yield of 70% is applied, resulting in 440 kg coal waste per tonne coal beneficiated and assuming 80% is in the form of discard (with the balance as fines slurry). Total coal waste is derived from the overall yield for the coal mining industry in 2014 (77%) (DMR, 2015) and an assumed yield of 98% for coal undergoing crushing and destoning only. The derived value aligns with available industry data (average value of SACRM mine data sample is 73%, with a range from 54%-80%). The estimate of 80% of total waste reporting as discard is according to a national inventory of discard and duff coal in South Africa in 2001. Reference(s): Department of Minerals and Resources (2015) South Africa's Mineral Industry (SAMI) 2014/2015. Pretoria; The South African Coal Roadmap (SACRM) (2011). Overview of the South African Coal Value Chain. http://www.sanedi.org.za/archived/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/sacrm%20value%20chain%20overview.pdf; DMR (2001) National Inventory Discard and Duff Coal - 2--1 Summary Report, Department of Mineral resources of South Africa Available at: http://www.energy.gov.za/Coal/coal_discard_report.pdf. (Accessed August 2017).

exchanges.description: Emission factor for low temperature oxidation of coal taken from South Africa's National GHG Inventory for post-mining coal handling and storage (0.18 m3/tonne, underground mine). Emission factor is for underground coal only, with surface coal given an emission factor of 0. The emissions are therefore adjusted for the percenatge of coal undergoing washing supplied from surface mines. Reference:  Department of Environment (2014) GHG NATIONAL INVENTORY REPORT SOUTH AFRICA 2000 -2010, November 2014. http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/natc/zafnir1.pdf

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=RER
Water purchased from water boards is assumed to be potable water. Total water use in coal washing is assumed to be 150 litres/tonne ROM, with12% of this purchased water. A slightly lower water use value is applied than that in Pulles et al. (2001) (which has an average value of 217 litres/tonne ROM  from a sample of 32 mines) to account for improvements in coal dewatering since 2001 (Johan de Korte, 2017). ReferencesThe sources of water on the mines is also obtained from Pullles et al. (2001), with the 12% purchased figure obtained from an average of 41 mines. Water figures are adjusted to exclude water for human consumption.References: Pulles, W., Boer, R. & Nel, S. 2001. A Generic Water Balance for the South African Coal Mining Industry. Water 
Research Commission Report No. 801/1/01.; Johan de Korte, Senior Researcher, Council for Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR), telephonic interview, 7 June 2017.

exchanges.description: Approximate value, calculated from concentration in representative sample of effluent multiplied by estimate of volume of water discharged to rivers (industry data).

Calculated value, assuming 13% of water loss is as a result of evaporation. Share of water loss to evaporation is taken from Pulles et al. (2001). Total water use by washing is assumed to be 150  litres/tonne ROM, A slightly lower value is applied than in Pulles et al. (2001) (which has an average value of 217 litres/tonne ROM  from a sample of 32 mines) to account for improvements in coal dewatering since 2001 (Johan de Korte, 2017). References: Pulles, W., Boer, R. & Nel, S. 2001. A Generic Water Balance for the South African Coal Mining Industry. Water Research Commission Report No. 801/1/01.; Johan de Korte, Senior Researcher, Council for Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR), telephonic interview, 7 June 2017.

Average share of water used in coal washing filled by water extracted from rivers from Pulles et al. (2001), in which a sample of 41 mines found that river water supplied 32% of the water used on the mine. Total water use by coal washing is taken to be 150  litres/tonne ROM, A slightly lower value is applied than that in Pulles et al. (2001) (which has an average value of 217 litres/tonne ROM  from a sample of 32 mines) to account for improvements in coal dewatering since 2001 (Johan de Korte, 2017). References: Pulles, W., Boer, R. & Nel, S. 2001. A Generic Water Balance for the South African Coal Mining Industry. Water Research Commission Report No. 801/1/01.; Johan de Korte, Senior Researcher, Council for Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR), telephonic interview, 7 June 2017.
